topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Tamar Yehoshua, her roles at Glean, Slack, Google, and Amazon, and previews topics including leadership, cross-functional work, and AI strategy.

topics.title: Career success habits: excel and understand people
topics.summary: Tamar shares two core drivers of her success: doing an exceptional job in your current role (beyond table stakes) and developing deep understanding of people’s motivations for both product building and leadership.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Explo (embedded analytics) and Sprig (product experience insights and AI recommendations).

topics.title: Learning to read the room and motivations
topics.summary: Tamar explains how observing reactions and asking questions builds intuition for what users and teammates want, drawing on lessons from her psychiatrist father about analyzing social dynamics.

topics.title: Balancing metrics with intuition and perspective
topics.summary: She cautions against over-reliance on metrics, advocating for customer intuition, “beginner’s mind,” and earning UI prominence by focusing on what users are trying to accomplish rather than pushing pet features.

topics.title: What “doing a great job” really means
topics.summary: Tamar reframes performance as business impact—building things people use and moving the company forward—and shares an early-career story where she declined a management role because the team shouldn’t exist.

topics.title: Companies can win while being poorly run
topics.summary: They discuss how internal dysfunction (turnover, broken processes, unhappy teams) doesn’t always correlate with business success, and Tamar highlights what matters most: product people want, distribution/sales, and runway.

topics.title: Hypergrowth chaos: why it happens and limits
topics.summary: Tamar explains why hypergrowth creates operational breakage and communication issues, when chaos is acceptable vs harmful, and how scaling eventually requires stronger processes and professional management.

topics.title: You don’t need a career plan: follow people
topics.summary: Tamar argues five-year plans aren’t necessary; instead, optimize for learning by following exceptional people and talent hubs, building durable skills and networks rather than trying to predict outcomes.

topics.title: Choosing roles: recruitability and avoiding mercenary traps
topics.summary: She advises leaders to pick jobs where hiring will “make people’s careers,” warns that financial outcomes are hard to predict, and notes even strong careers include missteps and companies that don’t work out.

topics.title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos: principles and long-termism
topics.summary: Tamar recounts quarterly meetings with Bezos: six-pagers, listening-first leadership, exceptional depth, and the power of consistent principles; she shares his view that fewer resources can be an advantage over the long term.

topics.title: Lessons from Stewart Butterfield: vision and prototyping
topics.summary: She describes Stewart’s enduring 2014 Slack master plan and his insistence on prototyping to ‘feel’ product changes, including an extreme prototype that hid the entire UI behind one button to rethink information architecture.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Sidebar, a peer-group platform for senior tech leaders to get feedback, career support, and facilitated programming.

topics.title: Making time for prototypes: mindset and tech stack
topics.summary: Tamar explains prototyping can be faster if engineering infrastructure supports it, teams embrace throwaway code, and design/engineering collaborate; they note AI tools are making prototyping even easier.

topics.title: Other leadership lessons: Benioff’s marketing as product
topics.summary: Tamar highlights Marc Benioff’s marketing mastery, describing how Dreamforce and keynote strategy reflect product-like thinking and bold competitive positioning.

topics.title: Building strong PM–engineering partnerships and alignment
topics.summary: Prompted by feedback from Fuzzy Khos, Tamar shares how to build cross-functional trust: choose a strong engineering partner, clarify ownership, avoid ‘mom vs dad’ dynamics, and create alignment through shared reviews and OKR rituals.

topics.title: Don’t over-index on unhappy users during changes
topics.summary: Tamar explains why product teams shouldn’t be trapped by the vocal minority when removing or redesigning features; instead design for future scale while being transparent, respectful, and giving users time to adapt.
